title: Business Live: Wednesday, 9 October
text:
CHARLES MCQUILLAN Copyright: CHARLES MCQUILLAN

Paschal Donohoe (pictured), the Irish finance minister, unveiled a cautious budget for 2020 on Tuesday on the assumption of a no-deal Brexit.

It includes new spending of €2.9bn of which €1.2bn was earmarked for a no-deal Brexit.

Neil Gibson, chief economist at EY Ireland, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the finance minister was sending a "signal that they were willing and able to step in and provide some financial support to the firms most affected".

"Although they did allocate some of it across different departments, helping tourism, helping agriculture, they were quite rightly a little bit circumspect on exactly how that would be given out because, as they admit, they can’t be sure exactly how a no deal would affect the economy," he said.

Nothing has been ruled out in terms of the support for firms, Mr Gibson added.

Brexit, he said, was coming at a time when the Irish economy is "booming" with 300,000 jobs added in five years. While there was “no appetite for no-deal Brexit", he said, "if you are going to face something as disruptive as they at least they are doing it the point where its close to the top of the economic cycle”.

Brexit was likely to hit rural areas most, he stressed, as some financial services firms are moving to Ireland from the UK.
